label: Dal Ka Dulha
description: Dal ka dulha, also known as dal pithi or dal pithori, is a dish from Bihari cuisine that's popular in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar. The dish is made with whole-wheat dumplings that are stuffed with arhar dal and then dipped in spicy lentils.
cuisines: It’s a comforting dish where whole wheat flour is used to make small dumplings — usually shaped like bow ties or rolled and pinched discs — which are then simmered in arhar/toor dal (pigeon peas). These dumplings absorb the flavor of the dal and spices as they cook, making it hearty and filling.
method: Wash the lentils, boil them with turmeric and salt in a cooker for 10 minutes.
Knead the dough and roll it into rotis.
Cut out rounds with a bowl and shape them to make dumplings.
Add dumplings to the boiled dal and simmer for 10–15 minutes.
Heat oil in a pan, crackle cumin and asafoetida, then add garlic, ginger, and curry leaves.
Add chopped onions, fry till golden, then add tomatoes and powdered spices.
Once spices are roasted, pour into the dal, mix well, and bring to a boil.

label: Chawal Ka Fara
description: Fara, made from rice flour, is a much-loved dish in UP. Phere made from rice flour is also called desi momos. Rice flour contains choline, which helps in taking cholesterol and triglycerides from the liver into the body.
cuisines: Chawal Ka Fara is a traditional steamed dumpling dish made from rice flour and a spiced chana dal filling, popular in Chhattisgarh and Eastern Uttar Pradesh. Soft on the outside and flavorful inside, these healthy dumplings are often enjoyed as a light snack or breakfast.

ingredients.item: For slightly chewy, fluffy white rice, mix rice with

method: Gather all the ingredients.
Take rice flour and cooked rice in a bowl.
Add salt as per taste and mix well.
Add a little water and knead it like dough.
Apply some oil and make the dough smooth.
Make small balls and give them long shapes.
Apply ghee in a plate and keep it aside.
Pour some water in a bowl and place a strainer over it.
Place the farra on the sieve and cover it with a plate.
Cook on low flame for 10 to 15 minutes.
Serve the prepared fara with spicy green chutney.

label: Nimona
description: Nimona is a green peas curry that's a winter delicacy in Uttar Pradesh and other northern regions. This recipe uses coriander, garlic, ginger, green chili, and some water, and is made with green chutney paste, chopped tomatoes, and fried potato wedges.
cuisines: Nimona is a rebellious shapeshifter who teams up with villain Ballister Blackheart to fight against a corrupt institution. Set in a futuristic medieval world, the story blends action, humor, and heart, exploring themes of identity, trust, and acceptance.
method: In a blender, puree 1 cup of green peas with 2 tablespoons of water.
Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a deep pan and fry sliced potatoes until light golden brown.
Add the green peas puree to the same pan and cook for 3–4 minutes.
Add mashed tomatoes and cook on medium heat for 2 minutes.
In the same pan, heat 2 more tablespoons of oil and add bay leaf, cardamom, and cumin seeds, and sauté for 30 seconds.
Add mashed tomatoes and cook again on medium heat for 2 minutes.
Add the prepared green masala paste and turmeric powder, and sauté on medium heat for 2 minutes.

label: Rasawa
description: Rasawa is also the name of a seasonal Lucknowi recipe that's similar to kheer and made with sugarcane juice and rice. It was a favorite of Hindus and Muslims in Lucknow, and was a must have during Holi celebrations.
cuisines: Rasawa is a typical rural village located in eastern Uttar Pradesh, within the Purvanchal region. Surrounded by fertile agricultural land, Rasawa reflects the traditional lifestyle and culture of rural India, particularly the Bhojpuri-speaking belt.
method: Add tomatoes, salt, and turmeric, and sautÃ© until tomatoes break down and become mushy.
Add ground spice powder, and sautÃ© for 2â€“3 minutes, until the spice powder smells good.
Add water, tamarind, and jaggery, and bring to a boil.
Simmer for 5 minutes, then stir well.
Taste, and add more salt, jaggery, or tamarind to adjust the flavor.
Add chopped coriander leaves, and simmer for a minute.
Cover and turn off the stove.

label: Kachalu Chaat
description: Kachalu chaat, also known as kachaloo chaat, is a popular Indian street food made with kachalu, a root vegetable with a mild, nutty taste and starchy texture. Here's a recipe for kachalu chaat.
cuisines: Kachalu Chaat is a tangy and spicy North Indian street food made with boiled kachalu (a variety of colocasia root). Tossed with bold spices like red chili, roasted cumin, chaat masala, tamarind pulp, and lemon juice, it’s garnished with green chilies and fresh coriander. This flavorful dish is known for its unique texture and zesty taste, making it a popular monsoon or festive snack.
method: Wash and boil 2 kachalu.
Let them cool, then peel and cut into small pieces.
Add red chili powder, salt, roasted jeera powder, chaat masala, and black pepper powder.
Add 2 finely chopped green chilies.
Add coriander leaves, tamarind pulp, and lemon juice.
Mix well with a spatula, then cover and let sit for 1–2 hours.
Garnish with coriander and squeeze lemon juice on top.

label: Dahi Ka Chilla
description: Curd cheela is good for health. It contains nutritious carbohydrates. It is also a good remedy for allergies and can cure digestive problems. There are about 120 calories in one cheela.
cuisines: Dahi Ka Chilla is a soft, savory pancake made with a batter of curd (dahi), gram flour (besan), and spices. Lightly spiced and often mixed with chopped vegetables or herbs, it's cooked on a tawa until golden. This protein-rich, quick-to-make dish is a popular breakfast or snack option in Indian households, loved for its tangy flavor and fluffy texture.
method: In a mixing bowl, add half a bowl of wheat flour.
Add finely chopped onion, tomato, green chili, and coriander.
Mix in 1 teaspoon salt, 1 teaspoon red chili powder, and 1/2 teaspoon turmeric.
Add curd and water gradually to make a smooth, pourable batter.
Let the batter rest for 10–15 minutes.
Heat a non-stick pan and add 1 teaspoon oil.
Pour a ladleful of batter onto the pan and spread it gently into a round chilla shape.
Cook on medium heat until golden brown on both sides, using a little oil as needed.
Repeat for the remaining batter and serve hot with chutney or curd.

label: Bajre Ki Roti
description: Bajre ki roti, or pearl millet roti, is a traditional Indian flatbread made from bajra flour, which comes from the pearl millet grain. The dough typically includes the following ingredients: Bajra flour (pearl millet flour), Salt, Water, and Sunflower oil or ghee.
cuisines: Bajre Ki Roti is a traditional Indian flatbread made from pearl millet flour (bajra). Dense, earthy, and gluten-free, it is typically served hot with ghee, jaggery, or spicy curries. Popular in Rajasthan, Gujarat, and Haryana, this nutritious roti is rich in fiber and essential minerals, making it a hearty and wholesome addition to any meal, especially in winter.

ingredients.item: Make a well in the center and add warm water
Knead the dough until it's soft
ingredients.quantity: Knead the dough until it's soft

ingredients.item: Take a portion of the dough and knead it slightly
ingredients.quantity: Take a portion of the dough and knead it slightly

ingredients.item: Shape the dough into a ball
ingredients.quantity: Shape the dough into a ball

ingredients.item: You can cook the roti on a tawa or griddle
ingredients.quantity: You can cook the roti on a tawa or griddle

ingredients.item: Bajre ki roti is gluten-free, so the dough is delicate
ingredients.quantity: Bajre ki roti is gluten-free, so the dough is delicate

ingredients.item: You can leave out the fats if you prefer
ingredients.quantity: You can leave out the fats if you prefer

method: In a large bowl, mix bajra flour and salt.
Add ½ cup of warm water and knead until the dough is soft.
Take a small piece of dough and knead it into a ball.
Lightly flatten the ball, dust with pearl millet flour, and spread into a small disc.
Dust your work surface with pearl millet flour, place the disc on it, dust again, and gently tap and spread to form a thin disc.
Heat a non-stick tawa, put the disc on it, add some water, and cook on medium heat for 1–2 minutes per side.
Serve hot with makhan.

label: Bathua Ka Raita
description: Bathua ka raita is a refreshing North Indian dip made with yogurt and bathua leaves. Bathua is a green leafy vegetable also known as Chenopodium album, lamb's quarter, goosefoot, or pigweed.
cuisines: Bathua Ka Raita is a refreshing and nutritious North Indian side dish made with curd (yogurt) and bathua (chenopodium or pigweed leaves). Lightly spiced and blended with boiled or blanched bathua, it offers a cooling, earthy flavor. Often served with parathas or rice meals, this seasonal raita is popular in winter for its digestive and health benefits.
method: Wash and blanch bathua leaves.
Chop and store the leaves.
In a small bowl, whisk together curd, salt, and other ingredients.
Heat ghee in a pan and add cumin seeds and green chilies.
Saute until light brown, then pour into the curd mixture.
Mix well.
Add a little water or milk to thin the raita.
Top with chopped green chilies.

label: Biya Ki Sabji
description: Biya Bhaji is a popular and spicy vegetarian dish of Goa. It is also called cashew curry or cashew tonak. It is usually prepared with fresh coconut and spices and served with roti, rice, or bread. Biya Bhaji is served at weddings and other special occasions in Goa.
cuisines: Biya Ki Sabji is a traditional dish made from raw jackfruit, often enjoyed during festive or special occasions. This flavorful sabji combines curd and aromatic spices, offering a meaty texture and rich taste similar to a non-vegetarian curry.
method: Boil or pressure cook the raw jackfruit pieces until soft but not mushy. Drain and keep aside.
In a bowl, whisk curd with chili powder, turmeric, garam masala, kasuri methi, ginger garlic paste, and salt. Set aside.
Heat oil in a pan. Add bay leaves, cinnamon, cardamom, cloves, and cumin seeds. Sauté until aromatic.
Add the boiled jackfruit pieces and fry for 3–4 minutes on medium flame.
Pour the curd-spice mixture into the pan and mix gently with the jackfruit.
Cook on low flame, stirring occasionally, until the masala coats the jackfruit and oil separates.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves if desired and serve hot with chapati or rice.

label: Puri Ki Lapsi
description: Lapsi of Puri is a traditional Guyanese dessert, consisting of lapsi (a white, thick pudding) sandwiched between a puri (small fried flatbread). This sweet is usually made in the Hindu community and offered to Hindu deities, especially Durga, Kali, and Ganga. However, it can also be eaten as a sweet.
cuisines: Puri Ki Lapsi is a traditional Rajasthani sweet dish made with broken wheat (dalia), ghee, jaggery, and dry fruits. This wholesome and aromatic dessert is often prepared during festivals or special occasions, offering a delightful blend of texture and flavor.
method: Dry roast the broken wheat (dalia) until aromatic.
Transfer it to a bowl, add 3 spoons of ghee, and keep it covered.
Add water to jaggery and allow it to dissolve completely. Keep aside.
Boil milk in a separate pan and add 1/2 bowl of water.
Let it come to a rolling boil.
Chop dates into small pieces and add them to the boiling liquid.
Grind cloves, cardamom, cinnamon, and nutmeg into a powder and add to the mixture.
Add the ghee-coated dalia to the boiling mixture.
Once it is partially cooked, add the dissolved jaggery and cook until the mixture thickens.
Stir in raisins, chopped almonds, cashews, and pistachios.
Finally, add sliced dry coconut and saffron strands.
Serve warm, garnished with flaked almonds.

label: Neem Aam Ka Paana
description: Mango Panna is a great drink for summers. It is good for digestion, increases energy levels and also helps fight depression. Mango Panna contains Vitamin A, which is beneficial for the eyes.
cuisines: Neem Aam Ka Paana is a refreshing and tangy summer drink made from raw mangoes, infused with spices, mint, and a hint of neem for a detoxifying twist. It’s perfect for beating the heat and rehydrating the body naturally.
method: Add 1 cup of water to the raw mangoes and boil until soft.
Scoop out the pulp and grind it with sugar, black salt, green chili, ginger, and mint leaves in a mixer.
Add 1 liter of cold water to the ground pulp and strain the mixture.
Mix in roasted cumin powder and adjust salt if needed.
Serve chilled with ice cubes.
Garnish with fresh mint leaves before serving (optional).

label: Matha Aloo
description: Matha aloo, also known as dahi aloo, is a popular North Indian dish of boiled potatoes and yogurt.You can adjust the spice level to your taste. To make the dish sweeter and sourer, you can add a bit of sugar.
cuisines: Matha Aloo is a traditional North Indian dish made with boiled potatoes simmered in a spiced yogurt (matha or buttermilk) gravy. It's a comforting, mildly tangy curry seasoned with cumin, green chilies, and sometimes fenugreek or mustard seeds, giving it a rustic and earthy flavor. Often enjoyed during fasting (vrat) or as a light summer meal, this dish pairs beautifully with plain rice, roti, or kuttu ki puri.
method: Boil the potatoes until soft, peel them, and lightly mash or cube them.
Heat oil or ghee in a pan. Add cumin seeds and asafoetida. Let them sizzle.
Add curry leaves, chopped green chilies, and ginger-garlic paste. Sauté until aromatic.
Add mashed potatoes, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well.
Stir in the whisked yogurt and cook on low flame for 3–4 minutes, stirring continuously.
Simmer until the curry thickens slightly and flavors blend well.
Turn off the heat and garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve hot with roti, puri, or steamed rice.

label: Jaggery Amla Murbba
description: I am almost surprised but kind of grateful that Amla (Indian Gooseberry) has not made it to the superfood genre yet. I am also kind of kicking myself for not attempting to make Amla Murabba at home earlier.
cuisines: Jaggery Amla Murabba is a traditional Indian sweet preserve made by slowly cooking amla (Indian gooseberry) in jaggery syrup. Rich in vitamin C and iron, this murabba combines the tanginess of amla with the natural sweetness of jaggery, offering both taste and health benefits. Commonly consumed to boost immunity, aid digestion, and improve skin health, it’s a popular remedy in Ayurvedic diets and winter wellness routines.
method: Heat a pot of water and to it add 2 tbsps vinegar and 2 tbsps baking powder and let the Aamlas soak in it for 20 minutes, then drain and wash well with plain water.
Prick holes into the Aamlas with a fork uniformly and set aside.

Bring another pot of water to boil. Water should be enough to soak aamlas well. Once boiling, keeping the flame high, add the aamlas into boiling water and boil for 15 minutes, then drain and keep aside.
While Aamlas are boiling prepare the sugar syrup by mixing 2 cups sugar with 2.5 cups water (or 3 cups sugar with 3.5 cups water) on a medium-high flame.

Reduce the flame once the sugar is dissolved and add Aamlaas; continue to simmer for an hour or until Aamalas are soft and start to shrivel. Check for doneness by piercing with a fork; the fork should glide in easily.
Turn off heat, bring to room temperature and store in an air tight container for 2-3 days in a cool, dry place. Since here in Hong Kong it is quite humid right now, I placed it in the refrigerator.
Then reduce the flame and add the Aamlas and simmer for 5 minutes.
Use a dry spoon for serving to prevent spoilage.

label: Dal Palak Shorba
description: Dal palak shorba is thinner in consistency than soup and a great way to start your meal. A warm and comforting dish with the goodness of lentils, spinach, ginger-garlic and mild spices. Season with fresh cream and a generous squeeze of lime.
cuisines: Dal Palak Shorba is a hearty and nutritious Indian soup made with yellow lentils (dal) and fresh spinach (palak). Lightly spiced and gently simmered, this warming dish combines the earthy flavors of lentils with the freshness of greens. Often tempered with garlic, cumin, and ghee, it's rich in protein, iron, and fiber — making it a comforting and healthy addition to any meal, especially during cooler months.
method: Soak moong dal and tur dal (pigeon pea) in water for a couple of hours. After they have been soaked well, pressure cook them with spinach leaves in 4 cups of water. Make a paste and leave aside.

Heat oil in a pan. Once done, add cumin seeds till they splutter. Then add finely chopped ginger and garlic. Saute them till the raw aroma goes away. When they are slightly browned, add garam masala, turmeric powder, chopped chillies and a pinch of asafoetida.
Fry this mixture on low flame and then add the dal and spinach paste. You can add some water to adjust the consistency.
Add thick cream to the simmering dal, season with salt and lemon juice.

label: Chana Ghughari
description: Chana Ghughri is very famous in Bihar. Some cloves make it juicy. And some cloves make it dry. It tastes very good. Chana Ghughri made of desi black gram tastes very tasty.
cuisines: Chana Ghughari is a simple and flavorful Indian snack made from boiled black chickpeas (kala chana), commonly enjoyed in states like Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh, and Bihar. Lightly spiced with mustard seeds, green chilies, and turmeric, it's often garnished with fresh coriander and a dash of lemon juice. Nutritious and protein-rich, Chana Ghughari is a wholesome tea-time snack or breakfast option, especially popular during festivals or fasting days.
method: Soak black gram in water for 8 hours, then wash them thoroughly, put them in the cooker and cook for one whistle, add a little salt too.
Now put oil in the pan. Add asafoetida, cumin seeds and chopped green chillies in it, then add onions. When the onions turn pink, add chopped tomatoes.
When tomatoes melt, add turmeric, red chilli, coriander, salt and garam masala to it. Now add boiled gram. Cook for 5 minutes. Add juice of 1/2 lemon.
Here, Bihari Chana Ghughri is ready for all of you.

label: Turmeric Hony Milk
description: However, people with kidney problems should avoid drinking turmeric milk, as it may worsen kidney stones or cause them to form in large quantities. Too much turmeric may also make it difficult for the body to absorb iron, which could lead to iron deficiency.
cuisines: Turmeric Honey Milk, also known as Golden Milk, is a soothing and health-boosting drink made by blending warm milk with turmeric and a touch of honey. Known for its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, this traditional Ayurvedic remedy supports immunity, improves digestion, and promotes better sleep. Often enjoyed before bedtime, it's a comforting and natural wellness tonic.
method: Add a pinch of ground black pepper to help your body absorb the turmeric.
Add other spices like cinnamon, cardamom, or clove while boiling for extra health benefits.
If you're using honey, wait until the milk has cooled to a warm temperature before adding it.
Drink turmeric milk while it's still warm.
Limit yourself to one serving of turmeric milk per day to avoid side effects.

label: Tulsi Aloevera Sharbat
description: This juice helps to clear the blood and it also helps in joint pain. Relieves the body of detox (harmful elements). This juice increases metabolism in our body. This juice increases good cholesterol by lowering the levels of bed cholesterol, which helps in reducing obesity.
cuisines: Tulsi Aloe Vera Sharbat is a refreshing and herbal Indian drink made from the medicinal blend of tulsi (holy basil) and aloe vera. Known for its detoxifying and immunity-boosting properties, this sharbat helps cool the body, supports digestion, and promotes skin health. Naturally soothing and mildly sweet, it's perfect for summer hydration and Ayurvedic wellness.
method: Prepare all ingredients.
Wash the aloe vera leaf to remove dirt and impurities.
Remove the edges of the leaf and slice it.
Scoop out the gel with a spoon and place it in a blender.
Add tulsi leaves, chopped ginger, and chilies.
Add one cup of water and sweeteners such as honey and lemon juice.
Blend the mixture until smooth.
Add ice cubes, brown sugar, salt, cumin powder, pepper powder, and lemon zest to a bowl.
Strain the juice and mix well with the ingredients in the bowl.

label: Kokum Sol Khadi
description: Solkadhi recipe (also known as solkadi, sol kadhi, kokum kadhi or kokum curry) is an essential drink for cooling the body during blistering Goan summers. This mauve-hued, tart digestive beverage is easy to make, and takes just 10 minutes of active time to prepare.
cuisines: Kokum Sol Kadhi is a cooling, tangy drink from the coastal regions of India, especially Goa and Maharashtra, made using kokum (a sour fruit) and coconut milk. Infused with garlic, green chili, and cumin, this mildly spiced beverage aids digestion and is typically served as a refreshing accompaniment to meals or as a light appetizer during summer.
method: Rinse 12 kokums under cool water. Place them in a bowl and add 1 cup water.
Soak the kokums in the water for 30 minutes.
After 30 minutes, completely crush and squeeze kokum in the water by using your fingers.
Pour the kokum extract in a strainer placed atop a bowl.
The kokum shreds will collect in the strainer.
Press the kokum shreds with a spoon to extract as much flavor as possible.
Then add 2 cups water to the kokum extract.
Next add 1 to 1.5 cups thick coconut milk. You can either make the coconut milk or use canned coconut milk.

label: Banana Daliya
description: Bathua ka raita is a refreshing North Indian dip made with yogurt and bathua leaves. Bathua is a green leafy vegetable also known as Chenopodium album, lamb's quarter, goosefoot, or pigweed.
cuisines: Bathua Ka Raita is a refreshing and nutritious North Indian side dish made with curd (yogurt) and bathua (chenopodium or pigweed leaves). Lightly spiced and blended with boiled or blanched bathua, it offers a cooling, earthy flavor. Often served with parathas or rice meals, this seasonal raita is popular in winter for its digestive and health benefits.
method: Wash and blanch bathua leaves.
Chop and store the leaves.
In a small bowl, whisk together curd, salt, and other ingredients.
Heat ghee in a pan and add cumin seeds and green chilies.
Saute until light brown, then pour into the curd mixture.
Mix well.
Add a little water or milk to thin the raita.
Top with chopped green chilies.

label: Moringa Ki Sabji
description: Moringa or drumstick vegetable is a treasure trove of nutrients. Moringa vegetable, which is very beneficial for health, is beneficial in many diseases. It is especially used in bone pain. Regular consumption of Moringa also strengthens the liver and digestion.
cuisines: Moringa, also known as drumstick or Sahjan, is a highly nutritious plant native to parts of India and Africa. Rich in vitamins A, C, and E, calcium, and antioxidants, both its leaves and pods are used in traditional cooking and medicine. Moringa leaves are commonly added to dals, curries, and soups, while the long pods are often cooked in sambhar and stews. Known for its immunity-boosting and anti-inflammatory properties, moringa is considered a superfood in many cultures.
method: To make Moringa or Drumstick Sabzi, first peel the Moringa pods. After this, cut them into long pieces. After this, cut the potatoes into small pieces. Instead of cutting the tomatoes, make a big incision on them. Now put potatoes, tomatoes, Moringa pods, water and salt as per taste in a pressure cooker. Put the lid on the cooker and let it whistle 2-3 times and then turn off the gas.

Heat oil in a pan. When the oil is hot, add cumin seeds and crackle them for 8-10 seconds. After this, add finely chopped onion (if desired, onion paste) and let it cook on low flame. After some time, add coriander powder, turmeric, red chili powder and mix and let the masala cook. Meanwhile, open the cooker and strain the vegetables and use the water in the gravy.

After this, take tomatoes, peel them and fry them in onion masala. After cooking tomatoes for some time, add boiled drumstick pods and potatoes and mix. Then add the water of the pods as well. Add salt to the vegetable as per taste and let it cook. When the vegetable boils well, turn off the gas. The tasty and nutritious Moringa vegetable is ready. You can garnish it with green coriander leaves and eat it anytime for lunch or dinner.

label: Moong Dal Khichdi
description: Moong dal khichdi is easy to digest and provides a good balance of protein, carbohydrates, and nutrients. Moong dal is a yellow-skinned lentil that's high in protein and fiber, and helps you feel full for longer.
cuisines: Moong Dal Khichdi is a simple, comforting, and nourishing one-pot dish made from split yellow moong dal (lentils) and rice. Soft, mildly spiced, and easy on the stomach, it's often considered a healing food in Indian households — especially for those recovering from illness or looking for a light, nutritious meal.
method: Wash and soak equal parts basmati rice and moong dal for 30 minutes.
In a pressure cooker or pot over medium heat, heat ghee and add cumin seeds and bay leaf.
When the seeds sputter, add ginger and sauté until fragrant.
Add onions and green chilies and sauté until soft.
Add tomatoes, carrots, beans, salt, and turmeric. Cook for 2–3 minutes.
Add the drained rice and dal to the cooker and mix well.
Add 4 cups of water for a porridge-like consistency or 3 cups for a mushy consistency.
Cover and cook on medium flame for 2 whistles (or simmer covered in a pot until soft and mushy).
Mash the khichdi slightly with the back of a spoon for a thicker texture, if desired.
Serve hot with a drizzle of ghee, papad, and pickle.

label: Vegitable Daliya
description: Vegetable dalia is a healthy, tasty, and mildly spicy Indian dish made with broken wheat, also known as cracked wheat, bulgur wheat, or couscous, and vegetables.
cuisines: Moong Dal Khichdi is a traditional Indian comfort food made from split yellow moong dal and rice, simmered together with mild spices. Light, wholesome, and easy to digest, it's a go-to meal for both everyday nourishment and times of illness or detox.
method: Roast dalia: Heat ghee or oil in a pan and roast dalia (cracked wheat) for 2–3 minutes until aromatic. (Skip if not using dalia.)

Sauté: In a pressure cooker, heat oil or ghee. Add cumin seeds, finely chopped ginger, green chilies, and chopped onion. Sauté until the onion turns translucent and the raw smell of ginger disappears.
Add vegetables: Add chopped tomatoes, potatoes, carrots, and peas. Sauté for 2–3 minutes.
Add remaining ingredients: Add washed moong dal, turmeric powder, and salt to taste. Sauté for another 2 minutes to blend flavors.
Pressure cook: Pour in 4 cups of water and pressure cook for 2–3 whistles (or simmer until soft if using a pot).
Finish: Once pressure releases, stir in a little butter (optional), sambar powder (for a South Indian twist), and chopped coriander leaves. Let it simmer for 1–2 more minutes before serving.

label: Moong Dal Palak Cheela
description: Moong Dal Palak Cheela can also be served with tomato sauce or green coriander chutney. The cheela batter should neither be too thin nor too thick. It is better to use non-stick pan to make cheela.
cuisines: Moong Dal Palak Cheela is a nutritious and protein-rich savory Indian pancake made from soaked moong dal (split yellow lentils) blended with fresh spinach (palak) and spices. Crisp on the edges and soft in the center, these cheelas are a healthy, gluten-free alternative to traditional breakfast or snack options.
method: Soak yellow moong dal in water for 2 hours.
Drain the dal and blend it with ½ cup of water until smooth to form a batter.
Add chopped spinach, green chili paste, ginger paste, asafoetida, chili powder, turmeric, crushed cumin seeds, salt, and about ¼ cup more water. Mix well.
Heat a non-stick griddle (tava) and lightly grease it with oil.
Pour a ladleful of batter onto the griddle and gently spread into a 7-inch circle.
Cook for 1 minute on medium heat until the underside starts to firm up.
Brush a little oil on top and around the edges of the cheela.
Cook until the base turns light golden and the top is dry.
Flip and cook the other side if desired (optional for extra crispiness).
Serve hot with green chutney, pickle, or tomato sauce.

label: Tandoori Masala Mushroom
description: Tandoori mushrooms are a healthy Indian appetizer made by marinating mushrooms in yogurt and spices, then grilling or roasting. Here's a recipe for tandoori mushrooms using an air fryer.
cuisines: Tandoori Masala Mushroom is a smoky, spicy Indian appetizer made by marinating white button mushrooms in a flavorful blend of yogurt, spices, and aromatic whole masalas. Air-fried or grilled until golden and slightly charred, this dish offers the essence of tandoori cooking without needing a clay oven. The mushrooms soak up the marinade beautifully, making each bite juicy, creamy, and packed with bold, layered flavors.
method: Preheat the air fryer to 180°C (356°F).
Clean the mushrooms and make gentle cross incisions on each one to help the marinade seep in.
In a bowl, mix together ginger-green chili paste, salt, and mushrooms. Toss to coat well.
In a separate bowl, mix cashew nut paste with a cheesy garlic mayo (or whisked yogurt).
Add the mayo/yogurt mixture to the mushrooms, squeeze in some lemon juice, and mix well.
Season with salt and crushed black peppercorns. Let the mushrooms marinate for 15–20 minutes.
Place the marinated mushrooms in the air fryer basket. Drizzle any remaining marinade over them.
Air fry for 15 minutes or until slightly charred and golden.
Serve hot, garnished with onion rings, lemon wedges, and fresh coriander.

label: Grilled Masala Fish
description: Grilled masala fish is a popular dish in Karachi that's spicy and tangy, with crispy skin and moist, soft flesh.Some fish that work well for grilling include salmon, tuna, shrimp, whole trout, mahimahi, and snapper.
cuisines: Grilled Masala Fish is a flavorful and aromatic dish where fish fillets are coated in a spiced marinade made from ginger-garlic paste, chili powder, coriander powder, turmeric, lemon juice, and garam masala. Marinated to perfection and grilled until charred and flaky, this dish is a delicious balance of tangy, spicy, and smoky flavors. It’s best enjoyed with lemon wedges, mint chutney, or a fresh salad, and makes for a light yet satisfying meal.
method: In a bowl, mix chili powder, turmeric, coriander powder, garam masala, ginger garlic paste, salt, and lemon juice to form a thick marinade.
Coat the fish pieces evenly with the marinade and let them rest for 30 minutes to 1 hour.
Preheat the grill to medium or high heat.
Line a baking tray with foil and lightly brush it with oil.
Place the marinated fish on the tray and grill for 8–10 minutes per side, or until the fish is cooked through and flakes easily.
Baste the fish with oil while grilling to keep it moist.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve hot with lemon wedges or green chutney.

label: Tandoori Chicken
description: Tandoori chicken is a dish of chicken that's marinated in yogurt and spices and then roasted in a tandoor, a cylindrical clay oven. The dish originated in Punjab before India's partition and became popular in the late 1940s at the Moti Mahal restaurant in New Delhi.
cuisines: Tandoori Chicken is a classic North Indian dish known for its smoky, spicy flavor and vibrant red hue. Marinated in thick yogurt and a blend of spices including Kashmiri chili powder, turmeric, and lemon juice, the chicken is traditionally cooked in a tandoor (clay oven) but can also be grilled or roasted in a regular oven. The marinade tenderizes the meat while infusing it with rich, tangy, and aromatic flavors, making it a favorite in Indian cuisine.
method: In a bowl, whisk together thick yogurt, garlic paste, ginger paste, lemon juice, Kashmiri chili powder, turmeric powder, vegetable oil, and salt.
Cut deep slashes into the chicken pieces (3–4 on thighs/legs or 2–3 on drumsticks) to help the marinade penetrate.
Brush the marinade generously all over the chicken, making sure it gets into the slashes.
Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 5–6 hours or overnight, turning occasionally for even marination.
Preheat the oven to 230°C (450°F/gas mark 8).
Line a roasting tin with foil and place a wire rack on top.
Place the marinated chicken pieces on the rack and roast for 10–15 minutes or until cooked through and lightly charred.
The chicken is done when the juices run clear or when pierced with a knife and no pink remains inside.
Serve hot with mint chutney, lemon wedges, and onion rings.

label: Dal Palak
description: Dal palak, or spinach dal, is a protein-rich Indian dish made with lentils, spinach, spices, and herbs.Dal palak can be served with rice, roti, chapati, or bhakri.
cuisines: Dal Palak is a hearty and wholesome Indian dish made by simmering lentils (usually toor dal, moong dal, or a mix) with fresh spinach (palak) and a blend of aromatic spices. This comforting curry combines the protein-rich goodness of lentils with the iron and fiber of spinach, making it both nutritious and satisfying.

ingredients.item: Split yellow lentils (moong or toor dal)

method: Rinse and soak 1 cup of split yellow lentils (moong or toor dal) for 15–20 minutes, then drain.
In a pot or pressure cooker, add the dal with 2½ to 3 cups of water, turmeric, and a pinch of salt. Cook until soft (2–3 whistles in a pressure cooker or 20–25 minutes simmering in a pot).
While the dal is cooking, heat rapeseed oil in a pan over medium heat.
Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add finely chopped or grated ginger and sauté for a minute.
Add chili flakes and cook for a few seconds.
Add chopped spinach and cook until wilted (about 3–4 minutes).
Once the dal is cooked, mash it lightly with a spoon or whisk for a smoother texture.
Add the sautéed spinach mixture to the dal and stir well.
Simmer the combined mixture for 5–7 minutes, adjusting water for desired consistency.
Season with salt and black pepper to taste.
Serve hot with steamed rice or roti.

label: Masala Chaas
description: Masala chaas, also known as spiced buttermilk, is a popular Indian drink made from yogurt, water, and spices and herbs.Masala chaas is refreshing and cooling, and is often consumed on hot summer days or with spicy meals. It's vegetarian, gluten free, and low carb.
cuisines: Masala Chaas is a refreshing, spiced Indian buttermilk drink made by blending yogurt with water and infusing it with traditional spices and herbs. Light, cooling, and tangy, it’s especially popular during the hot summer months and is known for aiding digestion.

ingredients.quantity: ½ cup (if using alternate blending method)

method: In a blender, grind together ½ cup of curd, 1 tsp chopped green chili, 1 tsp chopped mint, 1 tsp chopped ginger, 1 tsp chopped coriander, 1 tsp chaas masala, and 1 tsp pudina powder into a smooth paste.
Transfer the mixture to a bowl and add ¼ cup milk and ¼ cup water. Mix well.
Add 1 cup of plain yogurt and 2 cups of chilled water. Whisk or blend again until frothy.
Season with black salt, roasted cumin powder, and chaat masala (if using).
If needed, strain the chaas to remove any rough herb particles.
Garnish with chopped coriander or mint leaves.
Serve chilled.

label: Moong Dal Cheela
description: You can make the chilla soft or crisp. For a soft chilla, pour and spread the batter lightly. For a crisp chilla, spread the batter thinly and add extra oil. You can serve moong dal chilla with pickles, chutneys, ginger chai, or curries.
cuisines: Moong Dal Cheela is a light and nutritious North Indian savory pancake made from ground soaked moong dal, spices, and vegetables like carrot and coriander. It’s a popular breakfast or snack option, often served with green chutney.

ingredients.quantity: 2 to 4 tablespoons ghee or 2 tablespoons oil

method: Rinse and soak 1 cup of moong dal in 2–3 cups of water for 3–4 hours, or until it doubles in size.
Discard the water and add the moong dal to a blender or grinder along with ¼ cup of water.
Grind or blend until smooth and fine. If the lentils aren't grinding well, you can add 1–2 tablespoons more water.
Add ¼ teaspoon of turmeric powder, ¼ teaspoon of red chili powder, and ½ teaspoon of roasted cumin powder or cumin powder.
Heat a cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat and add oil or ghee to coat the pan.
Pour a ladleful of batter onto the pan and spread it into a circle from the center outwards.
Cook for 2–3 minutes until the underside is browned, then flip and cook until the other side is golden.
Serve with green chutney.

label: Tandoori Soya Chaap
description: Tandoori soya chaap is a vegetarian Indian dish of soybean skewers that are marinated and grilled until browned and charred. Arrange the soya chaap, onions, and peppers on the wire rack and grill for 15 minutes.
cuisines: Tandoori Soya Chaap is a delicious North Indian vegetarian dish where soy protein sticks are marinated in a spiced yogurt mixture and grilled or roasted until smoky and charred. It’s a popular plant-based alternative to tandoori meat dishes, often served with mint chutney and onions.
method: Cut 4–5 chaap sticks into 1/2-inch pieces.
In a bowl, mix all the marination ingredients.
Add the soya chaap pieces to the bowl and mix well to coat.
Cover and marinate in the fridge for 30 minutes to 2 hours.
Thread the chaap pieces onto metal skewers.
Cook over direct flame until browned and slightly charred.
Transfer the cooked chaap to a bowl and toss with serving ingredients.
Serve with green chutney, thinly sliced onions, and lime wedges.

label: Tandoori Fish Tikka
description: Tandoori fish tikka is a popular, low-carb appetizer of boneless fish pieces coated in a thick tandoori marinade and grilled in a tandoor, a clay oven. The fish is cooked until crispy and has a smoky flavor from the fats dripping onto the hot coals while grilling.
cuisines: Tandoori Fish Tikka is a popular North Indian seafood appetizer made by marinating fish fillets in spiced yogurt and then grilling or baking them to smoky perfection. It's a healthy and flavorful dish often served with lemon wedges, onion slices, and green chutney.
method: In a bowl, combine hung yogurt, chili powder, garam masala, salt, dried fenugreek powder, ginger-garlic paste, lemon juice, and mustard oil to make a marinade.
Add fish cubes to the marinade and mix until well coated.
Marinate for 1–2 hours.
Preheat the oven to 200°C.
Skewer the fish cubes with other ingredients like onion, tomato, and capsicum.
Grease a baking tray with butter and place the skewers on top.
Bake for 20 minutes.
Baste the fish with butter every 10 minutes to make it crispy.
Serve with lemon, onion roundels, and chaat masala.

label: Lassoni Palak Corn Bhurji
description: Lasooni corn palak is a creamy spinach curry with sweet corn and a spicy, garlicky tadka. You can also watch a video of a restaurant-style lasooni corn palak recipe.
cuisines: Lassoni Palak Corn Bhurji is a savory North Indian dish made with garlic-flavored spinach and sweet corn, cooked together with aromatic spices and a rich tadka. It’s a healthy and flavorful side dish perfect for lunch or dinner.
method: Sauté garlic and green chilies in ghee until fragrant.
Fry onions until soft and translucent.
Add spinach and coriander and cook until wilted.
Cook tomatoes with whole spices until soft and pulpy.
Cook ground spices for a minute or two to remove the raw flavor.
Add palak puree, corn, and cream.
Make tadka.
Serve.

label: Tandoori Mushroom Tikka
description: To make mushroom tikka, you can marinate mushrooms in yogurt, spices, and other ingredients, then cook them on skewers in the oven, air fryer, or on the stove.
cuisines: Tandoori Mushroom Tikka is a flavorful North Indian appetizer made by marinating mushrooms and vegetables in spiced curd and roasting them until smoky and charred. It's a vegetarian alternative to classic tandoori dishes, popular at BBQs and dinner parties.
method: In a bowl, mix together hung curd, ginger-garlic paste, chili powder, garam masala, kasoori methi, salt, lemon juice, mustard oil, roasted gram flour, ajwain, and kala namak.
Add mushrooms and capsicum to the marinade and coat well. Let it rest for 30 minutes.
Thread the marinated vegetables onto skewers.
Place skewers on a greased baking tray.
Bake in a preheated oven at 200°C (392°F) for 10–12 minutes or until slightly charred.
Brush with butter and serve hot with green chutney.

label: Besan Halwa In Jaggery Pwd
description: Besan halwa can be a healthy snack or breakfast food, and it's adaptable to your taste. It contains healthy fats, magnesium, fiber-rich almonds, and whole grains. Besan halwa is an Indian dessert made with gram flour, jaggery, ghee,milk and nuts.
cuisines: Besan Halwa made with jaggery powder is a wholesome and aromatic Indian dessert. It is prepared by roasting gram flour (besan) in ghee, then sweetened with jaggery and flavored with dry ginger, cardamom, saffron, and turmeric. A nourishing and comforting sweet treat, especially enjoyed in winters.
method: Heat ghee in a heavy-bottomed pan on low heat.
Add besan and roast it on low flame until golden brown and aromatic. Stir continuously to avoid burning.
Add dry ginger powder, turmeric, cardamom, and black pepper. Mix well.
Slowly pour in warm milk while stirring to avoid lumps.
Once the mixture thickens, add jaggery powder and continue stirring.
Cook until the halwa starts leaving the sides of the pan and ghee separates.
Add saffron and chopped nuts. Mix well.
Serve warm, garnished with more nuts if desired.

label: Soya Nuts Proteen Bar
description: Soya Bar is a nutritious snack made up with soybean flour, dried fruits and nuts. It offers delicious ways to enjoy goodness of soy including oats, almonds, walnut, jaggery, honey, sesame and coconut flakes.
cuisines: The Soya Nuts Protein Bar is a healthy, energy-packed snack combining roasted oats, nuts, dried fruits, soy flour, and natural sweeteners like jaggery and honey. Perfect as a pre/post-workout bite or a mid-day energy boost, these bars are nutrient-dense and rich in plant-based protein, fiber, and essential fats.
method: Heat a pan and dry roast the oats, sesame seeds, and soy flour until aromatic. Set aside.
In the same pan, lightly toast the almonds, walnuts, and coconut flakes.
In a saucepan, melt jaggery with honey on low heat until it forms a smooth syrup. Stir constantly to avoid burning.
Add condensed milk and stir until well mixed.
Add all roasted dry ingredients along with apricots, raisins, and figs into the syrup mixture.
Stir continuously until the mixture thickens and everything is well coated.
Grease a tray or square pan with vegetable oil and pour the mixture into it.
Flatten the top with a spatula or press with oiled hands.
Let it cool completely at room temperature, then refrigerate for 30 minutes to set.
Cut into bars and store in an airtight container.

label: Roasted Makhana Chaat
description: Makhanas are gluten-free, high in carbohydrates, and rich in protein. They can also be fried in ghee until they pop, similar to popcorn, and eaten with black salt as a snack.
cuisines: Roasted Makhana Chaat is a light, crunchy, and tangy Indian snack combining roasted foxnuts (makhana) with creamy yogurt, chutneys, spices, and fresh toppings. It's a fusion of textures—soft curd, crisp makhana, crunchy sev, and bursts of sweetness from pomegranate—making it a refreshing and nutritious chaat option.

ingredients.item: Jaggery powder (or a pinch of sugar)

method: Heat ghee or a little oil in a pan over low to medium heat.
Add makhana and roast, stirring frequently, until crisp but not browned. Remove and let cool.
In a mixing bowl, whisk together the yogurt with jaggery powder (if using), turmeric (if using), and a pinch of salt until smooth and slightly frothy.
Fold in the roasted makhana, roasted peanuts, and roasted chana into the yogurt mixture gently so they retain some crunch.
In a serving bowl, spoon the makhana-yogurt mix.
Drizzle tamarind chutney and green chutney over the top.
Sprinkle roasted cumin powder, chaat masala, kala namak, and red chili powder evenly.
Top with finely chopped onion, tomato, pomegranate arils, and fresh coriander.
Garnish with sev and mint leaves just before serving to keep the sev crisp.
Serve immediately.

label: Bombay Potatoes
description: A popular Indian side dish made with boiled potatoes sautéed in aromatic spices.
cuisines: Bombay Potatoes are a flavorful and spicy Indian dish where boiled potatoes are tossed with cumin, mustard seeds, onions, tomatoes, and a blend of ground spices. It's a quick and easy recipe often served as a side with roti, naan, or rice. The crispy edges and soft centers of the potatoes absorb the rich masala, making each bite deliciously bold and comforting.
method: Boil the potatoes until fork-tender. Peel and dice them. Set aside.
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add mustard seeds and cumin seeds; let them splutter.
Add chopped onion and sauté until golden brown.
Add garlic and ginger. Cook for 1–2 minutes until fragrant.
Stir in chopped tomatoes and cook until soft.
Add turmeric, coriander powder, chili powder, and salt. Mix well.
Add the boiled potatoes and toss to coat evenly with the spices.
Cook for 5–7 minutes, stirring occasionally. Add a splash of water if it’s too dry.
Sprinkle garam masala and lemon juice (if using).
Garnish with chopped fresh coriander and green chilies if desired.
Serve hot with roti, naan, or rice.

label: Antipasto Platter
description: A traditional Italian appetizer platter with a variety of cured meats, cheeses, olives, marinated vegetables, and breadsticks. Perfect for gatherings and celebrations.
cuisines: A traditional Italian appetizer platter with a variety of cured meats, cheeses, olives, marinated vegetables, and breadsticks. Perfect for gatherings and celebrations.
method: Arrange meats and cheeses in separate sections on a large serving platter.
Fill small bowls with olives and marinated vegetables and place them around the platter.
Scatter cherry tomatoes and fresh basil leaves throughout for color and freshness.
Add grissini or sliced baguette on the side or center.
Drizzle a bit of balsamic glaze over the mozzarella or tomatoes if desired.
Serve immediately or chill slightly before serving.

label: Weelicious
description: A healthy and kid-friendly recipe from Weelicious, promoting nutritious meals for toddlers and families.
cuisines: A healthy and kid-friendly recipe from Weelicious, promoting nutritious meals for toddlers and families.
method: In a large bowl, mix together the flour, baking powder, salt, and cinnamon.
In another bowl, whisk together the eggs, milk, mashed banana, and vanilla extract.
Combine the wet and dry ingredients. Stir just until blended.
Heat a pan over medium heat and lightly grease it.
Pour batter to form pancakes and cook until bubbles form. Flip and cook until golden brown.
Serve warm with fresh fruit or a drizzle of honey.

label: Sweet Orange
description: A refreshing juice made from sweet oranges, perfect for breakfast or as a healthy refreshment.
cuisines: A refreshing juice made from sweet oranges, perfect for breakfast or as a healthy refreshment.
method: Wash the oranges thoroughly.
Cut them in half and extract the juice using a juicer.
Strain the juice to remove pulp and seeds (optional).
Add sugar or honey if desired, and mix well.
Serve chilled with ice cubes and garnish with mint leaves.

label: San Antonio
description: Makhanas are gluten-free, high in carbohydrates, and rich in protein. They can also be fried in ghee until they pop, similar to popcorn, and eaten with black salt as a snack.
cuisines: Roasted Makhana Chaat is a light, crunchy, and tangy Indian snack combining roasted foxnuts (makhana) with creamy yogurt, chutneys, spices, and fresh toppings. It's a fusion of textures—soft curd, crisp makhana, crunchy sev, and bursts of sweetness from pomegranate—making it a refreshing and nutritious chaat option.

ingredients.item: Jaggery powder (or a pinch of sugar)

method: Heat ghee or a little oil in a pan over low to medium heat.
Add makhana and roast, stirring frequently, until crisp but not browned. Remove and let cool.
In a mixing bowl, whisk together the yogurt with jaggery powder (if using), turmeric (if using), and a pinch of salt until smooth and slightly frothy.
Fold in the roasted makhana, roasted peanuts, and roasted chana into the yogurt mixture gently so they retain some crunch.
In a serving bowl, spoon the makhana-yogurt mix.
Drizzle tamarind chutney and green chutney over the top.
Sprinkle roasted cumin powder, chaat masala, kala namak, and red chili powder evenly.
Top with finely chopped onion, tomato, pomegranate arils, and fresh coriander.
Garnish with sev and mint leaves just before serving to keep the sev crisp.
Serve immediately.

label: Tripadvisor
description: A popular Indian sweet made by deep-frying flour batter in circular shapes, soaked in saffron sugar syrup. Crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside.
cuisines: A popular Indian sweet made by deep-frying flour batter in circular shapes, soaked in saffron sugar syrup. Crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside.
method: Dry roast the moong dal until golden and aromatic.
Add rice and enough water, pressure cook until soft.
Mash the cooked dal-rice mixture slightly.
Add jaggery syrup to the mixture and let it simmer.
Add coconut milk and mix well. Do not boil after adding coconut milk.
In another pan, heat ghee, roast cashews and raisins.
Add cardamom powder, roasted nuts, and ghee to the payasam.
Serve hot or chilled with vada or appalam.

label: Anipasto
description: Antipasto is a traditional Italian appetizer platter consisting of cured meats, cheeses, marinated vegetables, and olives. It's served before the main course to stimulate the appetite.
Antipasto is a traditional Italian appetizer platter consisting of cured meats, cheeses, marinated vegetables, and olives. It's served before the main course to stimulate the appetite.
method: Arrange cured meats in folds or rolls on a large platter.
Add mozzarella balls, cherry tomatoes, and marinated vegetables.
Sprinkle olives across the platter.
Garnish with fresh basil leaves.
Drizzle olive oil and optional balsamic glaze over the ingredients.
Serve with crusty bread or crackers if desired.

label: Honey Cake
description: Honey Cake is a classic Indian bakery-style dessert, especially popular in South Indian states like Tamil Nadu and Karnataka. Despite its name, honey is only a part of the sugar syrup poured over the cake after baking.
cuisines: Honey Cake is a soft, moist Indian-style sponge cake soaked in a honey-sugar syrup and topped with fruit jam and grated coconut. It's a nostalgic bakery favorite in South India, especially known for its bright red jam glaze and tender crumb.

ingredients.item: Fruit jam (usually mixed fruit or strawberry)

method: Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F). Grease and line a baking tin.
In a bowl, mix curd and sugar until the sugar dissolves. Add baking soda and baking powder, mix well, and rest for 5 minutes.
Add oil, vanilla extract, and milk to the mixture and combine.
Sift in the all-purpose flour and mix gently to form a smooth batter.
Pour the batter into the tin and bake for 25–30 minutes or until a toothpick inserted comes out clean.
While the cake bakes, make the syrup: heat water, sugar, and honey together until the sugar dissolves. Set aside.
Once the cake is out of the oven, cool slightly and poke small holes with a skewer.
Pour the honey syrup over the cake evenly and allow it to soak.
Heat jam slightly to make it spreadable and spread it over the soaked cake.
Sprinkle desiccated coconut generously on top.
Let the cake rest for an hour before slicing and serving.

label: Moong Dal Halwa
description: Moong dal halwa is a classic Indian dessert made from lentils, milk, sugar, ghee, and cardamom powder. The lentils are ground and fried until golden, then cooked with milk and sweetened with sugar.
cuisines: Moong Dal Halwa is a rich and indulgent Indian dessert made with yellow moong dal, ghee, sugar, and flavored with saffron and cardamom. Known for its grainy texture and melt-in-the-mouth richness, it's a festive favorite, especially in North India during winters and weddings.
method: Soak 1 cup of split and husked yellow moong dal in water overnight or for 4–5 hours.
Drain the water and grind the moong dal into a smooth, thick paste using minimal water.
In a heavy-bottomed pan, melt 9–10 tablespoons of ghee.
Add the ground moong dal paste and cook on low heat, stirring constantly, until the paste turns golden brown and develops a grainy, sandy texture.
In a separate pan, boil 2 cups water with sugar, saffron, and cardamom powder until the sugar is completely dissolved.
Add chopped nuts and grated khoya (if using) to the syrup and mix well.
Pour the syrup into the roasted moong dal and stir continuously until the mixture thickens and the halwa absorbs all the syrup.
Add more ghee if needed and continue stirring until glossy and aromatic.
Garnish with almonds, pistachios, and raisins. Serve hot.

label: Suji Halwa
description: Suji halwa, also known as sheera, is a traditional Indian dessert or pudding made from semolina, ghee, sugar, and other ingredients. It can be served for breakfast or dessert and is often offered as prasadam in temples or on special occasions.
cuisines: Suji Halwa is a classic Indian dessert made with semolina (rava), ghee, sugar, and dry fruits. It's quick to prepare and has a rich, nutty flavor with a soft texture. Often served during festivals or with puris and chana, this halwa is a beloved comfort sweet across India.
method: Heat ghee in a thick-bottomed pan over low to medium-low heat.
Add semolina (suji) and roast it, stirring continuously, until it becomes golden and emits a nutty aroma (around 5–10 minutes).
In a separate pan, bring water and sugar to a boil to create a sugar syrup.
Alternatively, microwave the water, sugar, and cardamom mixture for 2 minutes, stirring once, until the sugar dissolves.
Slowly add the sugar-water mixture to the roasted suji, stirring constantly to avoid lumps.
Reduce the heat to low and cook the mixture until ghee starts to separate and the suji becomes glossy and thick (about 5–7 minutes).
Add yellow food coloring if desired and mix well.
Garnish with almonds, raisins, and cashews.
Serve hot with puris and chana for a traditional touch.

label: Sweet Potato Gulab Jamun
description: Sweet potato gulab jamun is a North Indian dessert made from mashed sweet potatoes, flour, and a rose-flavored syrup. The dough balls are deep-fried and soaked in the syrup.
cuisines: Sweet Potato Gulab Jamun is a unique twist on the classic Indian dessert. Made with mashed sweet potatoes, flour, and milk powder, these deep-fried dumplings are soaked in saffron and clove-infused sugar syrup. Soft, juicy, and subtly spiced, they are a delicious and healthier variation of the traditional gulab jamun.
method: In a saucepan, combine sugar, water, cloves, and saffron threads. Bring to a boil and cook over high heat for 5–7 minutes until the syrup thickens. Remove from heat and let it rest.
In a large bowl, mash the sweet potatoes until smooth and lump-free.
Add baking soda, flour, and milk powder to the mashed sweet potatoes. Mix and knead until the dough is smooth.
Adjust consistency by adding milk if too dry or flour if too sticky.
Grease your hands lightly with ghee and form small, equal-sized balls from the dough.
Heat oil with some ghee in a pan. Deep fry the balls on medium heat until they turn deep brown.
Remove and place them on a paper towel to absorb excess oil.
While still warm, gently place the fried balls into the warm sugar syrup.
Let them soak for a few hours before serving for best results.

label: Jalebi
description: Jalebi is a popular Indian dessert made from a fermented batter of all-purpose flour, gram flour, and sugar syrup that's deep-fried in spirals or circles and soaked in sugar syrup. The batter should be thick but free-flowing, and the sugar syrup should be one-string consistency.
cuisines: Jalebi is a classic Indian dessert known for its crispy, spiral shape soaked in fragrant sugar syrup. Made with fermented all-purpose flour and yogurt batter, jalebi is deep-fried until golden and then soaked in syrup, making it sweet, crunchy, and juicy. Often enjoyed during festivals and special occasions.
method: Prepare the jalebi batter using flour, cornflour, yogurt, baking soda, food color, and water. Let it ferment for a few hours for a better texture.
Heat oil or ghee in a flat-bottomed pan over medium flame.
Pour the batter into a squeeze bottle or use a piping cloth with a small hole.
Pipe the batter into hot oil in spiral or concentric circle shapes.
Fry each jalebi until golden and crispy on both sides (around 2–3 minutes).
Immediately dip the fried jalebi in warm sugar syrup and let them soak for 30–60 seconds.
Remove and serve hot for best taste and texture.
Store leftovers in an airtight container at room temperature (2 days) or in the fridge (up to a week).

label: Almond Milk Rava Kesari
description: Almond milk rava kesari is a fragrant South Indian dessert made with semolina (rava), ghee, sugar, water, and almonds. You can also add other nuts and dried fruits, such as cashews, raisins, and sultanas, to rava kesari.
cuisines: Almond Milk Rava Kesari is a delicious South Indian dessert made with semolina (rava), homemade badam milk powder, ghee, and flavored with saffron and cardamom. This variation adds a rich almond flavor to the classic kesari, making it aromatic, creamy, and perfect for festive occasions.
method: Roast whole cardamom pods in a non-stick pan for 30 seconds until warm.
Peel and pound the cardamom using a mortar and pestle. Set aside.
Soak saffron strands in 2 teaspoons of warm milk.
Heat 1 tablespoon of ghee in the same pan and roast sliced almonds until golden. Set aside.
Add rava to the pan and roast on low heat for 2–3 minutes until aromatic but not burnt.
Pour milk into the pan and bring to a boil. Add badam milk powder, ground cardamom, and saffron.
Gradually add roasted rava while whisking to avoid lumps. Cook until it reaches a porridge-like texture.
Add sugar and stir continuously until it dissolves completely.
Continue stirring and cooking until the kesari thickens slightly.
Garnish with roasted almonds and serve warm.

label: Paruppu Payasam
description: Paruppu payasam, also known as moong dal payasam, is a traditional South Indian pudding made from soft cooked lentils, coconut milk, jaggery, and cardamom. The dish is often tempered with ghee and fried nuts, raisins, and sometimes coconut.
cuisines: Paruppu Payasam is a traditional South Indian dessert made with moong dal, jaggery, and coconut milk. It is often prepared during festivals like Onam and offered as prasad in temples. This creamy and mildly sweet dish is usually garnished with nuts and raisins, and can be served hot or cold with vada or appalam.
method: Dry roast the moong dal until golden and aromatic.
Boil dal (and optional rice) until soft and mushy.
Add jaggery syrup and stir well, letting it simmer for 5-7 minutes.
Add coconut milk and mix gently. Do not boil after adding coconut milk.
Heat ghee in a small pan, roast cashews and raisins until golden.
Add the roasted nuts and cardamom powder to the payasam.
Serve hot or cold, optionally with vada or appalam.

label: Ahe Ka Sheera
description: Atte ka sheera or atte ka halwa is a traditional Indian sweet made from wheat flour, ghee, and jaggery or sugar. It is generally prepared for festivals and offerings.
cuisines: Aate ka Sheera is a traditional Indian dessert made from wheat flour, ghee, sugar, and flavored with cardamom and nuts. It is typically served warm and enjoyed as a comfort sweet during festivals or after meals.

ingredients.quantity: As required (approx. 2 cups for halwa consistency)

method: Heat 1/2 cup ghee in a pan.
Add dry fruits and raisins, fry until golden, then filter and set aside.
In the same ghee, add wheat flour and roast on low flame for 5 to 6 minutes until aromatic and golden.
Gradually add water while stirring continuously to avoid lumps.
Add sugar and mix well.
Cook the mixture while stirring constantly.
If the halwa feels sticky, add more ghee one tablespoon at a time and mix well.
Add cardamom powder and fried nuts.
Mix thoroughly and serve warm.

label: Moti Choor Ladoo
description: Moti choor ladoo is a popular Indian dessert made from gram flour or besan (chickpea flour), sugar, water, and sometimes nuts and seeds. The flour is made into tiny balls called boondi, which are fried in ghee or oil and then simmered in sugar syrup until they plump up.
cuisines: Moti Choor Ladoo is a traditional Indian sweet made from tiny gram flour pearls (boondis), soaked in flavored sugar syrup, and shaped into round laddoos. It's commonly served during festivals and special occasions.
method: Heat sugar and water in a saucepan until the sugar dissolves, stirring often.
Cook until it reaches one string consistency, then remove from heat.
Add cardamom powder, rose essence, a few drops of orange food coloring, and lemon juice to the syrup.
Fry the boondis using besan batter and baking soda in hot oil.
Transfer the cooked boondis into the warm sugar syrup and mix well.
Let the mixture sit covered for 10 minutes so the syrup is absorbed.
Fluff the mixture, mix again, and shape into round ladoos.
Arrange on a plate, let cool, and store in an airtight container.

label: Kuchumbri Salad
description: Kachumber is a fresh, crunchy, and flavorful Indian salad that's made without dressing and typically contains cucumbers, tomatoes, onions, cilantro or mint, and spices.
cuisines: Kachumbari is a fresh, crunchy East African salad made from chopped vegetables like onions, tomatoes, and cucumbers, with a tangy lemon dressing. It’s typically served as a refreshing side with grilled meat, rice dishes, or stews.
method: Use fresh, crunchy vegetables for the best flavor.
Optionally soak chopped onions in water for 15 minutes to mellow their flavor.
In a large bowl, mix onion, tomato, carrot, cucumber, radish, green chili, and cilantro.
Add salt, black pepper, chili powder, cumin, and lime or lemon juice. Mix well.
For added texture and taste, mix in avocado, pomegranate, or sweet corn if desired.
Garnish with fresh herbs. Skip green chili for a kid-friendly version.
Serve immediately as a side with grilled dishes or rice.

label: Sprouted Salad
description: Sprouts salads can be made with many types of sprouts, including mung bean, alfalfa, moth bean, horse gram, red lentil, and black chickpea sprouts. Sprouts salads are rich in vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants, and can help maintain overall organ health.
cuisines: Sprouted Salad is a nutritious and refreshing mix of steamed sprouts and fresh vegetables, flavored with spices and lemon juice. It's a perfect light meal or healthy snack, rich in protein, fiber, and essential nutrients.
method: Boil or steam the moong sprouts until cooked but not mushy. For crunchier texture, partially cook them.
Finely chop onion, tomato, carrot, cucumber, radish, green chili, and cilantro.
In a large bowl, combine the cooked sprouts and chopped vegetables.
Add salt, black pepper, red chili powder, toasted cumin, and lemon juice. Toss well.
Optionally top with cornflakes, roasted poha, chopped mint, or grated coconut.
Serve immediately for maximum freshness and crunch.

label: Beetroot Banana Smoothie
description: Beetroot banana smoothies are a healthy, antioxidant-rich option that can be great after a workout.
cuisines: Beetroot Banana Smoothie is a healthy and vibrant smoothie packed with antioxidants and nutrients. It combines the earthy flavor of beetroot with the sweetness of banana and berries, perfect for breakfast or a post-workout refreshment.
method: Add banana, beetroot, and berries into a blender.
Pour in milk (dairy or non-dairy) and skimmed milk.
Add Greek yogurt, cinnamon, and lemon juice.
Blend until smooth and creamy.
Pour into a glass and serve chilled. Optionally garnish with seeds or mint.

label: Mango Lassi
description: Mango lassi is a popular Indian yogurt-based drink made with sweet mangoes, yogurt, milk, and cardamom. Mango lassi can be made vegan by using non-dairy yogurt and oat milk or water.
cuisines: Mango Lassi is a popular Indian yogurt-based drink made with ripe mangoes, curd, milk or ice, and flavored with cardamom. It's a refreshing and cooling beverage, perfect for summer.
method: Add chopped mangoes, cardamom powder, a few saffron strands (optional), and sugar into a blender.
Blend until the mixture becomes a smooth mango puree.
Add fresh curd to the blender.
Add milk or ice cubes and blend again until the mixture is creamy and smooth.
Pour into a serving glass and top with a pinch of cardamom or chopped nuts if desired.

label: Dried Fruits
description: Dried fruits are fruits that have had most of their water content removed through natural drying, dehydrators, or specialized dryers. They can be high in fiber, nutrients, and antioxidants, but also high in calories and sugar.
cuisines: Dried Fruits is a healthy snack made by dehydrating various fruits to preserve them and concentrate their natural sweetness. Common fruits used include bananas, figs, prunes, raisins, and mixed dried berries.
method: Use conventional drying for fruits with high sugar and acid content.
This traditional method is slow and may result in slightly lower-quality dried fruits.
Alternatively, use a dehydrator, which circulates warm air at low humidity to remove moisture efficiently.
Microwave drying is a faster method that can retain more fruit quality.
You can also use hot air drying, which involves exposing fruit to a continuous flow of warm air until moisture is removed.

label: Fresh Fruit Salad
description: Salads are popular because they are light and refreshing, and they are often high in fiber. They can help with weight management, lower the risk of cancer, and regulate cholesterol levels.
cuisines: Fresh Food Salad is a nutrient-rich, plant-based salad combining leafy greens, vibrant vegetables, seeds, and healthy fats, ideal for a light and wholesome meal.
method: Lay out spinach and kale on a clean towel to air-dry completely.
Tear up the dried greens into bite-sized pieces.
Toss the greens in a large mixing bowl.
Add chopped red cabbage, grated carrots, roasted squash, and steamed broccoli.
Add diced avocado, sunflower seeds, and pepitas.
Prepare your preferred dressing separately.
Drizzle the dressing over the salad.
Sprinkle with salt and pepper to taste, toss gently, and serve fresh.

label: Haldi Milk
description: Haldi milk is a home remedy for colds, coughs, congestion, and skin problems. It's also a nourishing bedtime drink that's beneficial for people with inflammation-related issues, poor immunity, or sleep disturbances.
cuisines: Haldi Milk, also known as Golden Milk, is a traditional Indian drink made by warming milk with turmeric and other spices. It is known for its immunity-boosting and anti-inflammatory properties.
method: In a saucepan, bring milk to a gentle boil over medium heat.
Add turmeric, cinnamon, ginger (fresh or powdered), and other optional spices like cardamom or cloves if desired.
Boil the mixture for about 2 minutes.
Turn off the heat and allow the milk to cool slightly until warm (but not too hot).
Add vanilla extract and ground black pepper, and stir well.
Sweeten with honey or maple syrup if desired.
Pour into a cup and enjoy warm.

label: Cucumber Raita
description: Cucumber raita is a refreshing, savory condiment made with yogurt, cucumber, and other ingredients. It's often served with biryani or pulao to enhance the flavor of the dish.
cuisines: Cucumber Raita is a refreshing Indian side dish made with chilled yogurt, cucumber, mint, and mild seasonings. It’s perfect to serve with spicy biryanis, pulao, or curries to balance the heat.

ingredients.item: Hot house cucumbers (peeled, seeded, thinly sliced)

method: Whisk the chilled Greek yogurt in a large mixing bowl until smooth.
Add the thinly sliced cucumbers, chopped mint leaves, lemon juice, sugar, and salt.
Mix everything well until evenly combined.
Taste and adjust salt or lemon juice as needed.
Optionally, garnish with a sprinkle of roasted cumin powder, ground black pepper, and chaat masala before serving.
Serve cold as a side dish with biryani, pulao, or any Indian meal.

label: Dal Chawal
description: Dal chawal, also known as dal bhat, is a dish of lentils and rice that is considered a healthy comfort food. It's packed with nutrients, including protein, fiber, vitamins, calcium, iron, folate, and potassium. The combination of dal and rice is also gut-friendly and can help with digestion and metabolism.
cuisines: Dal Chawal is a classic Indian comfort food dish consisting of steamed basmati rice served with a mildly spiced lentil curry made from toor dal and masoor dal. It's a wholesome, hearty, and nutritious meal widely enjoyed across India.
method: Wash 2 cups basmati rice thoroughly in a bowl until water runs clear.
Transfer the drained rice to a thick-bottomed pot. Add 3.5 cups water, 1/2 teaspoon salt, and 1 tablespoon coconut oil. Stir.
Cover and bring to a boil over high heat. Then reduce heat to low-medium and simmer for 15 minutes.
Turn off heat and let the rice rest for 10 minutes before fluffing. Set aside.
In another bowl, rinse 1/2 cup toor dal and 1/2 cup masoor dal with 2–3 cups water. Discard water.
Add 2 cups fresh water to the rinsed dals and let them soak.
Meanwhile, heat 2 tablespoons oil in a pan. Add 1 teaspoon cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add 1 chopped onion and sauté until golden.
Add 1 inch grated ginger, 3 crushed garlic cloves, and 1 slit green chili. Sauté for a minute.
Add 1/4 teaspoon hing and 1 cup tomato puree. Cook until the oil starts separating.
Add turmeric, cumin powder, coriander powder, and Kashmiri red chili powder (1/2 teaspoon each). Mix well.
Add the soaked dals and 2 cups water. Simmer until dals are soft and cooked.
Serve hot dal over steamed basmati rice.

label: Rajma Chawal
description: This Rajma recipe is a lightly spiced, creamy and delicious Punjabi style curry made with protein rich kidney beans, aromatics like onions, ginger, garlic, fragrant spices and tangy tomatoes.
cuisines: Rajma Chawal is a beloved North Indian comfort food made with red kidney beans (rajma) cooked in a spicy onion-tomato masala, served with steamed rice. It's hearty, protein-rich, and full of warming spices.
method: Sort and rinse 1 cup rajma. Soak overnight or at least 8 hours in enough water.
Drain soaked rajma, rinse again and add to a 3-liter pressure cooker with 3.5 to 4 cups water.
Pressure cook on high heat for 15–20 minutes or 18–20 whistles until soft. Set aside.
Heat 2 tablespoons butter in a pan over low-medium heat. Add 1/2 teaspoon cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add finely chopped onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add grated ginger, minced garlic, and chopped green chilies. Sauté for a minute.
Add 1 cup chopped tomatoes and cook until soft and mushy.
Add 1 teaspoon coriander powder, 1/4–1/2 teaspoon red chili powder, 1/4 teaspoon turmeric, and a pinch of hing. Mix well and cook until masala thickens and oil separates.
Add cooked rajma along with some of its cooking liquid. Mix and mash some beans to thicken.
Add 1.5 to 2 cups water (as needed for desired consistency) and simmer for 15–20 minutes.
Add 1/4–1/2 teaspoon garam masala, 1 teaspoon kasuri methi (crushed), and 2–3 tablespoons cream. Stir well.
Garnish with 1–2 tablespoons chopped coriander leaves.
Serve hot with steamed basmati rice (chawal).

label: Cholla Chawal
description: Punjabi Chole Masala is one of the most popular vegetarian curry dishes in India. It is a chickpea curry cooked with onions, tomatoes and lots of spices. Chole is one of those core curries in northern India without which no party or wedding festivities is complete.
cuisines: Cholla Chawal is a popular North Indian dish made with tender chickpeas cooked in a rich and aromatic blend of whole spices, typically served with steamed rice. It's a wholesome, protein-rich, and flavorful meal enjoyed across India.
method: Soak 2 cups of raw chickpeas overnight in enough water. In the morning, drain the water (you will get about 5 cups soaked).
Add the soaked chickpeas to a pressure cooker with 5 cups water and 1 teaspoon salt.
Pressure cook on high for 1–2 whistles, then reduce heat to medium and cook for another 10–12 minutes.
Turn off heat and let the pressure release naturally.
Once cool, open the lid and check if chickpeas are soft. If not, pressure cook for 2 more whistles.
Remove tea bags (if used), bay leaves, and cinnamon stick with tongs. Set cooked chickpeas aside.
Heat a pot or kadai on medium heat. Add 1 to 1.5 tablespoons oil.
Add 2 whole cloves and 3/4 cup grated onions.
Sauté the onions until the raw smell disappears and they turn light golden brown, about 7–8 minutes.
Prepare and add the ground masala from coriander seeds, cumin, pomegranate seeds, pepper, cardamom, cloves, red chilies, cinnamon, and ginger powder.
Add the boiled chickpeas, mix well, and simmer until flavors blend.
Serve hot with steamed rice (chawal).

label: Khicdhi Dahi
description: This Khichdi recipe is a light and easy to digest Indian dish made with rice and moong dal. Nutritious and light on the tummy, serve this healthy, comforting and nourishing porridge-like Dal Khichdi with curd, raita or papad.
cuisines: Khichdi Dahi is a comforting and wholesome North Indian dish made with moong dal and rice, lightly spiced and cooked until soft. It is typically served with yogurt (dahi) and ghee, making it a soothing meal perfect for digestion and nourishment.
method: Rinse 1/2 cup moong dal and 1/2 cup rice together. Soak them in water for 30 minutes.
Heat 2 tablespoons ghee in a 3-liter pressure cooker.
Add 1 teaspoon cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add 1/3 cup chopped onions and sauté until translucent.
Add 1/3 to 1/2 cup chopped tomatoes, 1/2 teaspoon green chillies, and 1 teaspoon chopped ginger.
Mix and cook until tomatoes soften.
Add 1/4 teaspoon turmeric powder and a pinch of asafoetida. Mix well.
Add the soaked and drained rice and moong dal. Stir for a minute to combine.
Add 3.5 cups water and salt to taste. Mix well.
Close the lid and pressure cook for 3–4 whistles or until soft and well-cooked.
Serve hot with yogurt (dahi) and extra ghee on top if desired.

label: Multigrain Khichdi
description: While this is not my go-to recipe, I do enjoy it occasionally. Let me unabashedly take credit for this recipe. It is totally my own creation! My goal was to make this recipe more wholesome. Great for a day when you donâ€™t have time to cook a lot, make it a tasty one-pot dish and get a whole lot of nutrients.
cuisines: Multigrain Khichdi is a hearty and nutritious one-pot meal made with a mix of whole grains, lentils, and fresh vegetables. Packed with fiber, protein, and essential nutrients, this wholesome dish is perfect for a healthy lunch or dinner and is easy to digest.
method: Soak brown rice, mung beans, millets, and flax seeds in water for about 2 hours.
Finely chop the vegetables: green beans, carrots, cabbage, tomato, and onion. Grate the ginger.
Turn on the Instant Pot in 'sauté' mode and add 2 teaspoons of ghee.
Once the pot is hot, optionally add mustard seeds or other seasoning ingredients if desired.
When the mustard seeds begin to crackle, add chopped vegetables and sauté for 2–3 minutes.
Add the soaked grains, grated ginger, and sea salt. Pour in 2 cups of water and stir everything well.
Close the Instant Pot lid, set to 'Pressure Cook' on high pressure for 30 minutes.
Once done, allow natural pressure release or quick release carefully.
Stir gently, add a spoon of ghee before serving, and enjoy hot with tomato chutney or yogurt.

label: Raggi Idli Coconuts
description: If you are an idli lover like I am, then this Ragi Idli is a recipe that you really canâ€™t miss. It is always good to have food, which is delicious as well as fits aptly on health parameters as well. An Idli as such is a healthy foodstuff.
cuisines: Ragi Idli is a nutritious South Indian steamed breakfast made with a fermented batter of finger millet (ragi), idli rice, urad dal, and poha. It combines the soft, fluffy texture of traditional idlis with the earthy flavor and high calcium content of ragi, making it a wholesome and diabetic-friendly option.
method: Take 1 cup idli rice in a bowl and rinse it a couple of times.
Add 1 to 1.5 cups of water to the rinsed rice and set it aside.
Rinse 1/4 cup thick poha once or twice, then add to the same bowl with rice. Mix well, cover, and soak for 4 to 5 hours.
In another bowl, take 1/2 cup urad dal and 1/4 teaspoon fenugreek seeds. Rinse a couple of times and soak in 1 cup of water for 4 to 5 hours.
After soaking, drain the urad dal and fenugreek and transfer them to a grinder or blender.
Grind into a smooth and fluffy batter, adding 1/3 to 1/2 cup water in parts while grinding.
Now, drain the soaked rice and poha and grind them in the same jar (in 2-3 batches if needed) until smooth or slightly coarse.
Combine the urad dal and rice batters in a large bowl. Add 1 cup ragi flour and mix well.
Add rock salt and mix thoroughly. Cover and ferment overnight or 8-10 hours until the batter rises.
Once fermented, pour the batter into greased idli moulds and steam for 10–12 minutes.
Serve hot with coconut chutney or sambar.

label: Tandoori Soya Chap Roll
description: For you to indulge in those flavours of tandoor, here we bring you a recipe of tandoori chaap that can be enjoyed by vegetarians as well as non-vegetarians.
cuisines: Tandoori Soya Chaap Roll is a delicious North Indian fusion dish where marinated soya chaap is grilled until charred and smoky, then wrapped in a soft roti or paratha with spicy, creamy sauces. Packed with protein and bold tandoori flavors, it's a perfect street-style snack or quick meal.

ingredients.quantity: As needed, sticks removed and cut into pieces

method: Remove the stick from the soya chaap and cut it into small bite-sized pieces.

In a mixing bowl, combine curd, ginger-garlic paste, red chilli powder, turmeric powder, tandoori masala, chaat masala, black pepper, salt, garam masala, kasuri methi, butter, fresh cream, and lemon juice.
Add the soya chaap pieces to the marinade and coat them well. Let it rest for 30 minutes.
Skewer the marinated chaap pieces onto metal or wooden skewers.
Grill or roast them over direct flame (or in a grill pan/oven) until nicely charred and cooked through.
Transfer the grilled chaap into a mixing bowl. Add additional cream, butter, lemon juice, or chaat masala if desired for serving.
Toss well and serve immediately — optionally rolled in a roti/paratha with onions, chutneys, and sauces to make a chaap roll.

label: Tawa Fry Fish
description: We've taken our basic fish fry to another level, the fish is fried yet it's succulent and coconut milk and tamarind and other spices come together to make it finger-licking goodness!.
